title: How should an aspiring author approach beginning to write their first book? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sit down and write it. If you’re a planner, outline the story, then write it. If you’re not that together, just start writing. You’ve read books (I hope, if you are an aspiring writer); you know what you like. One of two things will happen: Either you’ll write a few pages, or a few chapters, and realize you don’t love writing for its own sake, or You’ll finish your first novel. Once again, one of two things will happen. You’ll read it over (after a month or so) and say, “Wow, this is bad. I wonder how I can fix it…” You might have a friend with good literary taste read it to check for problems. Don’t be thin-skinned when he/she tells you what they are. Think about any criticism you get and try to figure out if it’s right. Or else you’ll say, “I’m never doing this again.” You can also ease into writing by starting with a short story or two before you leap into writing your first novel. Be advised: everyone’s first novel is bad. (What, everyone’s? Well, almost everyone’s. The chances are you will not be one of the very few whose first novel is great. ). The thing is, you get better with practice…unless you don’t. You will not earn a million dollars from writing. Probably. Some, probably a lot, of the criticism your writing will receive is deserved. Learn how to fix the problems. Keep writing if you love it. If you don’t, take up something you do love doing.

In my case, I started with a photo of when I was eight. And I never liked it. I probably would have burned it but my then girlfriend (now wife), told me not to. One photo was the inspiration to two books. Inspiration comes from all around and most times when you least expect it. My third book is very different. It's historical. That means I've spent almost five years in research and collection. It spans over 70 years. The inspiration is there but not all the facts I require. Be open and embrace the work and grind that it's going to take. Writing ain't an easy job.

I’m jumping the gun a bit, but you have to know this. You have to realize this. Don’t write five or ten pages or your first chapter…and then go back and read them and decide you have to make changes. You don’t not yet. Because that means you’ll end up doing it again. Any writer will tell you that you have to write every single day, and some days it might be good, others not so good, but you need to have a fair amount of days behind you to understand what your work looks like.

Research. I don’t care whether you’re a planner or a pantser. I’m a failed pantser, and I know why. (I’ve never published a book, btw). I didn’t do research. Grab the reader by the throat with the first word (no, no; don’t do that. That’s what made me not read Delirium). Get the grip of the way stories flow. Grab a book and read. Don’t be lazy; don’t be crazy. Just research… Oh, did you think I was going to say write? No. That’s why there are so many horribly written books in the world. Just research. And research, and research, and research. For a day. Then, next day, if at all you’ve felt like the research was enough, STOP and get to work. It’s pretty simple.
